University of Michigan, Population Studies Center, Ann Arbor, MI

PhD, July 2015, Sociology
Dissertation: “Parents’ Behavioral Adaptations to the Sex of Firstborn Children in the
Developing World.”
Committee: Paula England (co-chair), Dalton Conley (co-chair), Florencia Torche,
Jennifer Jennings, and Mike Hout (reader)
Subfields: Gender, Demography, Health and Medicine, Family Dynamics, Economic
Development, Natural Disasters and Displacement
New York University, Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, New York, NY
Weitzman, Abigail. “Women’s and Men’s Relative Status and Intimate Partner Violence in
India.” Population and Development Review. 40(1): 55-75.
• Profiled in The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, Reuters, The Hindu Times, and
over twenty international news outlets.
Weitzman, Abigail. “Does Fathers’ Sexual Behavior Vary with the Sex of Firstborns?
Evidence from Thirty-Seven Countries.” Journal of Health and Social Behavior. Forthcoming.
• Honorable Mention, Best Student Paper Award, ASA Section on Gender, 2014
• Honorable Mention, Best Student Paper Award, ASA Section on the Family, 2014
BOOK CHAPTERS AND OTHER PUBLICATIONS
Weitzman, Abigail. “(Pro)Creating a Crisis? Sex Ratios and Social Change in Developing
Countries.” Development in Crisis: Threats to Human Wellbeing in the Global South and the
Global North. Eds. Samuel Cohn and Rae Blumberg. New York: Routledge. 2015.
Weitzman, Abigail and Paula England. “Class and Sex for Young Women.” Invited
blogpost at Contexts. Dec. 10, 2014. http://blog.contexts.org/2014/12/07/class-and-sex
for-young-women/
ARTICLES UNDER REVIEW
* Denotes student co-author
Weitzman, Abigail. “Firstborn Sex and Maternal Wellbeing in India.”
Invitation to revise and resubmit at Social Forces.
• Best Student Paper Award, ASA Population Section, 2013
• Best Student Paper Award, ASA Section on the Family, 2013
Weitzman, Abigail, Jennifer Barber (UMich), Yasamin Kusunoki (UMich), and Paula
England (NYU). “Desire to Get Pregnant and the Desire to Avoid Pregnancy During the
Transition to Adulthood.” Second invitation to revise and resubmit at Demography.
Behrman, Julia* (NYU) and Abigail Weitzman. “The 2010 Earthquake and Inequalities in
Reproductive Health in Haiti.” Invitation to revise and resubmit at Studies in Family
Planning.
• Best Student Paper Award, ASA Section on Development, 2015
• Best Poster Award, PAA 2015
Weitzman, Abigail and Julia Behrman* (NYU). “Disaster, Disruption to Family Life, and
Intimate Partner Violence: The Case of the 2010 Earthquake in Haiti.” Under review.
Weitzman, Abigail. “Women’s Education and Intimate Partner Violence: Compulsory
Schooling Laws in Peru as a Natural Experiment.” Under review.

RESEARCH APPRENTICESHIPS
New York University, Graduate School of Arts and Sciences
Research Assistant to Paula England
• Cleaned data and conducted analyses for 2015 ASA Presidential Speech.
New York University, Graduate School of Arts and Sciences
Research Assistant to Florencia Torche
• Collected and compiled unique datasets.
New York University, Wagner Graduate School of Public Service
Research Assistant to Salo Coslovsky
• Reviewed and synthesized articles.
• Compiled information on the global sugarcane industry to be used in a grant proposal
to the National Science Foundation.
New York University, Graduate School of Arts and Sciences
Research Assistant to Eric Klinenberg
• Analyzed interview transcripts from hundreds of individuals and chose excerpts to be
included in Dr. Klinenberg’s book.
COURSES TAUGHT OR ASSISTED
Advanced Quantitative Analysis, NYU Applied Quantitative Research Program
Research Study Design, NYU Applied Quantitative Research Program
Research Study Design, NYU Applied Quantitative Research Program

Institutions, Governance, and Development, NYU Wagner School for Public Service 2012

PROFESSIONAL MEMBERSHIPS
ADDITIONAL EXPERIENCE
United Nations Development Fund for Women (UNIFEM), New York, NY
Communications and Resource Mobilization Intern
• Prepared educational resources for the launch of the Safe Cities Campaign, which
supports municipalities in developing strategies to reduce crime and make cities safer
for women.
• Coordinated the launch of the Global Virtual Knowledge Centre, an online resource
center offering a wide scope of research about violence against women.
Peace Corps Belize, Dangriga, Belize
Youth Development Volunteer
• Began the process of rewriting Belize’s HIV/AIDS national curriculum.
• Coordinated a four-month leadership academy for girls.
• Formed a self-help group for children with disabilities and their families.
• Developed age appropriate HIV/AIDS outreach tools and educational games for
children.
Peace Corps Peru, Puerto Eten, Peru
Youth Development Volunteer
• Oversaw a peer health educator program in two high schools, including the preparation
of interactive tools and other educational materials.
• Developed a program for pregnant teenagers combining income-generating skills, self-
esteem workshops, and information about pre and post-natal health care.
Initiated and ran an after-school tutoring and mentoring program for children
• Conducted anti-violence and self-awareness workshops in primary schools and with
mothers.
